story.headline: Kalimantan's Peatland Fires Release Billions of Tons of Carbon
story.summary: Kalimantan (Indonesian Borneo) contains some of the world's deepest tropical peatlands. Drainage for palm oil plantations and pulpwood has made these carbon-rich soils extremely fire-prone, turning the region into a major emissions source.
story.climateImpact: Peat fires burn underground for weeks or months, releasing massive quantities of CO₂ and particulate matter. During the 2015 fire crisis, Indonesia's daily emissions briefly exceeded those of the United States.
causeEffect: Drainage for palm oil and pulpwood lowers water tables
Exposed peat oxidizes and releases CO₂ continuously
Dry conditions trigger fires that burn deep into peat soil
Peat fires smolder underground for weeks, resisting suppression
Smoke haze affects health across Southeast Asia
story.scaleContext: Kalimantan's peatlands hold an estimated 57 billion tons of carbon. The 2015 fire season alone released an estimated 1.62 Gt CO₂e in just a few months. Annual fire detections via NASA FIRMS remain in the tens of thousands.
story.outlook: Indonesia has committed to peatland restoration, but enforcement is uneven. Without rewetting degraded peatlands, fire risk remains extreme during El Niño years.

title: Kalimantan's Peatland Fires Release Billions of Tons of Carbon
summary: Kalimantan's drained peatlands are extremely fire-prone, with the 2015 crisis releasing an estimated 1.62 Gt CO₂e in months.
